segments.text: First of all, now, about breakwater, what do you mean it's an altogether different principle or principle conceived of differently than it has been in the past?
Well, in the past, the whole matter of defending, let's say, a coast or a harbor against waves had been to pile in a lot of rock.
This does some absorption, some reflection.
It interferes with sand flow.
It can be disastrous.
It's irreversible.
There's no way to really tear it down once it's built.
We see these kinds of disasters all around the world where it's set up waves of beach erosion.
There's a static approach of sitting up there obstructing the waves by putting in a massive
chunks of rocks, sometimes wired together and cemented together.
This is a much more subtle way of destroying waves, which is to set something that causes the waves to destroy themselves.
It's driven by the pressure field and acts against the orbits of the wave.
And what you want is the least dense material rather than the most dense material.
You want it to have the greatest freedom of motion rather than the least freedom of motion.
And it truly degrades the waves into eddies, rather than reflecting it to a great extent, you see.
This is why the approaches to some coasts, to breakwaters, are rather dangerous, because you have these highly reflected waves.
So it's a totally different principle.
But I don't really limit it to that.
The whole business of intervening into the phase of the wave rather than the orbits of the wave is quite a different approach.
You have linked yourself into something that is, in principle, much more energetic.
That isn't quite the right way to say it, but rather that
The velocities involved are much higher than they are.
The rate at which the wave form is going across the ocean is much higher than the rate at which the water is moving.
Even Leonardo da Vinci understood that quite well.
I mean, what I mean even.
Leonardo da Vinci understood that one quite well.
But see, if you can link things into this rapid motion
of the velocity of the wave form across the ocean.
It's orders of magnitude greater than the actual water motion.
Most things, like a rubble mount breakwater, intervene with a orbital motion, a smaller motion.
This intervenes into the wave form itself.
If you can link that in so you get energy out also, then you've done a much more effective job.
You ordinarily only see this kind of linkage in the case of surfboarding, for example.
And then it's much degraded because it's been much slowed down.
But the velocities that are involved, you can already see are very high.
But if you can do this in the open sea, you see you're talking about velocities of 40 and 50 miles an hour.
You've linked to the pressure gradient.
I know one can't say when an idea first came to him along this way.
I realize that.
But roughly when did you begin to work on the problem in terms of...
Which one?
The problem of...
The breakwater?
The breakwater problem.
Well, I'd always had this in mind, more or less, in a kind of a vague, unformed, diaphanous way, since I'd worked on the torpedo net problem.
And every time I saw buoys that were partly hauled down, I was always impressed by their tremendously erratic motion.
And then how am I talking about it in class?
And I said, why don't we just really see, why don't somebody take the project to really seeing how one of these spheres behaves and how much energy it really, from the wave, it really does dissipate.
And one of the kids in the class took it up and looked at it and decided, yes, it was out of phase and did dissipate 30 or 40 times the energy that it would if it were held rigidly.
And then he dropped it, and then another kid took it up and really designed it through.
And he now has his PhD and is working for the state, building these things for the state of California, investigating that whole potential.
So how do you exactly say when such a thing comes up?
You see, I began to understand some years ago when we were working with
deep-sea moorings, where we made some deep-sea moorings that survived out in the Pacific three or four years in more than 3,000 fathoms of water.
But one of the reasons these survived was that they did behave something in this fashion.
And this allowed them, in a storm, to dodge the high waves.
They moved around the high waves rather than over them.
See, in a storm, the sea is a kind of stochastic topography of rapidly moving crests, of short crests.
And if you now put a buoy out there that is hauled down strongly and doesn't weigh much, it threads its way between these crests in a complicated pattern.
So it never gets hit by the highways.
It dodges them automatically.
And...
And it's clear this energy is coming from the waves, and that it's considerably more than just if the buoy were floating there and the waves were dragging against it.
So all of this sort of fits together, and you finally decide, well, maybe this is a real way to go.
So allow me to try it.
So in other words, a whole combination of ideas, you would argue, in terms of science, experimenting with both small things and large things,
drifts you into handling big problems.
And that's poorly put.
Let me try it this way.
It's that you begin with dealing with specifics, and then all of a sudden I look up and you're... And you observe something that's irrelevant, perhaps, to the specifics you're looking at.
And you store that away.
And it's an experience.
OK, now, like the iceberg, for example.
The other day, for instance, I was down on the beaches in Southern California, in Baja, California.
And there's loads of sand dollars.
And the sand is eroding by wind.
They're on the beach, in the dry beach.
And the sand is being driven very rapidly.
And these sand dollars, all of them,
slowly tilt up on little pinnacles of sand and take an attitude very much like the living organism does in the ocean.
Well, now that's strange.
You look at 100 or 200 of these things all standing up at the same angle, little pinnacle of sand behind them, holding them in that position.
And this is much the position, although they're not without the pinnacle of sand, that you see them in the actual ocean.
And you begin to wonder how much of this is

mediated through just the hydrodynamic shape of the sand dollar, you see, all facing into the wind, all with their top sides towards the wind, all at about almost 60 degrees inclination, all of them sitting there in like an array of these.
And sooner or later, maybe, I get a chance to maybe do some experiments on various sorts of creatures that live in a high, strong wave current regime, like sand dollars, bismuth clams, and whatnot.
Is their shape a particular hydrodynamic shape that gives it desirable properties, allows it to bury itself, orient itself, or something?
Or is this organically mediated through musculature, you see?
Interesting, isn't it, too?
So I think all kinds of little observations fit together sometimes.
And this is the case of the breakwater point, where loads of small observations lead you in some direction or another.
Well, I was also thinking about the concept of bringing down icebergs to furnish fresh water.
How did that occur to me?
Well, I want to know both how it occurred to you, and then I want your reaction.
I remember how it occurred to me exactly.

I was preparing, there was quite a bit of interest many years ago, and it keeps coming back periodically, of an underwater pipeline for Southern California to get its water from, God knows, Oregon, Washington, British Columbia, Alaska.
What a stupid idea in my way of thinking.
I mean, you don't know what's going on down there well enough.
There are landslides, there are instabilities.
There are all kinds of things, ships dropping their anchors and on and on.
But nevertheless, you can make the following calculation.
Let's say California needs 5 million acre feet of water a year.
OK, you can start to optimize this.
You can make a pipeline.
Now, the power to drive that water down that pipeline doesn't come free.
Even though you build a dam up there somewhere, you could have made electricity out of it, you see, rather than driving water.
So you think, well, I will optimize it.
very rapidly realized that, presently, optimization, just from the standpoint of loss, of frictional loss, comes with bigger and bigger pipelines.
And presently, you have a pipeline that has all the 5 million acre feet in it.
Well, now you might as well shirk it up more and just roll it into the ocean and tow it down.
Now you begin to optimize that.
It's a different concept.
Well, I was preparing very early in my days in the scripts, was preparing a talk about the water problem.
And one of the things I wanted to look at was the pipeline.
And when I optimized this thing, I came out with something that was half a mile in diameter and five miles long or some such a thing.
And it was optimum towing size.
And I thought, Jesus, such things exist.
They're the secondary tabular icebergs of the South Atlantic.
Let's see how these go.
What would be the milling rate?
What would be the thing?
And I made some calculations, and of course you come up with this interesting case that's a tome north from Antarctica.
You really tome to the east like mad because of their rotation and Coriolis force, if you wish.
And so these more recent studies by the Rand Corporation and so on on it...
rather thorough studies, go into the Coriolis force effect in a rather erudite fashion.
But of course, the simplest concept in the world gives you exactly the same answer.
It just says you've got to get that iceberg going 1,000 miles an hour to get it, not in respect to the water, but in respect to the fixed reference plane, to get it over the equator.

you got to tow it to the east to do this you got to get it going a thousand miles an hour to the east to uh to well to the west sorry you got to get it going a thousand miles an hour to the west to get over the equator and you got to tow essentially westwardly
That's correct, isn't it?
Good God, let's see.
I always have to go through this thing.
You've got to tow it to the east.
Good heavens, yes.
I was rotated there for a second.
You have to tow it to the east.
You have to get it going 1,000 miles an hour to bring it essentially to the velocity of the Earth.
Now, when I first remember reading about concepts of pulling icebergs to Southern California,
Now, I remember scientists making fun, in fact, of sort of jiving this concept, if I may use that word.
How do you feel as if when you introduce these ideas that long ago and it seems to be reaffirmed here in the present in terms of water shortages and ecological clashes?
Well, I don't think we'll ever do it in California.
You don't think you'll ever do it?
No.
Some other country I'll do it.
It's too outlandish.
The United States has lost a sense of adventure.
I had to examine that and examine that until hell froze over.
Worry about fogs and worry about fresh water influences and worry about this and that.
Never tried.
What do you attribute the loss of adventure to?
Oh, I guess sort of a degree of senescence, I would guess.
I don't know.
You could erect a thousand theories on this, I think.
We start out with a great deal of hybrid vigor in the United States.
We have people of all sorts of social proclivities mixing together.
And to some degree, they don't mix anymore, you see.
And I believe in heterosis.
That is the strength of hybridization.
And it only goes a generation or two, don't forget.
Well, that may be it.
Or it may be we're in the same position as a person on Easy Street.
Keep your finger on your number, as it were.
Don't take any chances.
There are the real concerns of the environmentalists, of course.
You have to look at these things.
They're real.
You can't kill off things in vast numbers.
But we've gone overboard on that, and it's a pendulum-swinging problem.
It may swing back again.
But I think that we can't do this sort of thing anymore in the United States.
We can't.
We can't.
Such a approach takes the agreement of a lot of people that you do need the water.
You're going to do it.
You're going to take some environmental losses.
You try to minimize those.
And it's too controversial.
The congressman has to take the path of least irritation rather than the path of rationality.
Man, as long as I have you here on the environment, I had some questions to ask you later.
May I ask them now?
Nuclear power.
Carry on.
You've just been through a referendum here in California.
Do you think referendums on nuclear power are essentially good things?
Referendums in which way?
Well.
You mean against or for?
Against or for.
I just, do you think that the public ought to make these kinds of decisions concerning the environment?
That's what I'm trying to find out.
Well, of course.
In the United States, we've fallen into the advocative position and
of our decisions are made by a series of advocates.
And this is kind of a long story.
I don't want to get into it too deeply.
But there's obviously a disparity between the scientific approach and the approach of advocacy.
takes only that evidence that supports his position.
That's the way the advocate does.
The scientist is forced into this system to advise.
And the advocate of the system says you're either with us or against us in no intermediate way.
The scientist is unable to express his reservations.
He's got to be gung-ho.
got to be in that direction or against that direction, one or the other, no ifs, ands, or buts.
And this is essentially an anathema to a scientist who really wants to evaluate things.
You can't be all for or all against.
This way, a budding scientist has such a hell of a problem with true, false, and questions.
There aren't any true-false questions.
They're answered true and false.
They're always reservations one way or another.
He either balances the reservations in which he probably fails, or he knows what the hell stupid answer the instructor really thinks is correct.
And that's the guy that makes it.
But you see, once he gets out into the real world and is asked for advice, he really can't do that and preserve his scientific equilibrium.
And so I think we get into this position of the scientist being essentially in a hopeless posture as far as advising the public.
The public can't see the uncertainties.
And if he expresses the uncertainties, then he's against it, whatever.
Well, in the case of nuclear power,
It's a long argument.
There are risks to everything, obviously.
I was out in the Pacific and saw the explosion of the Great Age bombs, many of them, 28 or something nuclear shots I've seen.
I've seen a vast amount of radioactivity thrown into the coral atolls.
The effect of it has been
Almost unobservable.
The ocean has an immense resiliency and capacity.
Exactly what a major spill would be from a nuclear power plant or a failure of containment of fuel, I really haven't looked into.
Clearly, you'd have some area that would be off limits.
But it can't be a disaster, you see.
It can't be a vast disaster.
But of course, you see, then again, we're up against the other problem of the utilities always plan for growth of existing areas.
So we have this self-fulfilling forecast in which

You want the power plant to supply power for the city of Los Angeles because the city of Los Angeles is going to grow, and then that's the only place it can grow because that's the only place there's power, and so on.
You know, the idiotic situation we're in.
I would like to see power sources put in places where there aren't anybody.
Then they might live there instead of, well, if they want to all live in Los Angeles, that's fine with me.
It leaves other places a little freer.
But our...
The number of forces that tend to concentrate us into these areas are insensate forces.
There are many of them.
One is the preparation for utilities.
That's one.
The other is, of course, loan and insurance policy and things of this nature.
You can't go out in the back country and build a house.
You can't get a loan on it.
You don't understand.
We're forced then to put these nuclear power plants, if we're going to put them, very close to highly utilized coastlines.
And intervening into a system that's already has very dense use.
Under those circumstances, that may be undesirable.
If we put one, if this were a free world really, planning the accommodation of man and this planet together, why wouldn't we put one down in Baja, California somewhere?
I both admire that and resent that.
I don't want any power plants in Baja, California or any place in the wilderness, I don't think.
I know that makes sense ecologically, what has to be done.

Well, as long as I have you on resilience of ocean, I read in Newsweek magazine last night, this is like the fourth or fifth time I've read that, where Jacques Cousteau, a naturalist, says in 30 years the ocean would be dead.
Do you resent that as a scientist?
Let's keep that off the record.
I don't want to be sued.
until I get my defense fund together.
All right.
I'll rephrase the question another way, then, I may, without involving any names.
I assume you believe the ocean is amazingly resilient in terms of recovery.
Do you think that the ocean should be exploited more, move into things like mariculture,
Well, let's stop at the first statement.
Exploitationist traps has the wrong connotation.
It certainly should be utilized more and with good sense, rationality, and dignity.
I think it can be a great deal more.
We know a great deal more about it than we did 30 years ago.
I've published rather extensively on exactly the same business, including Cousteau, if you wish.
And it's right here.
You probably have that.
Yeah.
And you don't have a match, do you?
No.
You may, for my answer about Christou, you can read that into the record right there.
Okay.
While I find a match.
Middle paragraph.
Yeah, right.
As a matter of fact, I had looked at that, and that was one of the things that interested me last night vis-a-vis this.
Well, I assume you believe this sort of adverse publicity towards utilization of the ocean affects only the process of oceanographers?
Affects what?
that it has a negative reaction upon oceanographers, that this kind of public opinion that these sorts of things stir up affects your work?
Well, sure, of course.
I don't really quite know how to answer that question, but let me say that I myself and a great number of other oceanographers have
have devoted a great deal of their lives trying to solve problems that society has in some way or another enunciated, that it said that they were important problems.
In several of these cases, we've solved these problems and solved them exquisitely.
I mean, much better than one would have expected they could have been solved.
The understanding of the pelagic fisheries versus the California current, for instance, I think is understood much better than anybody 20 years ago would have expected was ever obtainable.
We understand really something about the total nature of the population, how it fluctuates, what the interrelationships are, and what it's been like for 2,000 years.
We don't.
I think we really understand that.
And yet...

Public opinion is set up at a number of thoughtless people who keep saying, don't let the anchovy go as the sardine did, overfishing, on and on, and not allow the proper utilization of this environment.
Now, what you tend to leave behind you here is
the debris of dedicated scientists who were trying to serve society.
There's not much to ask a society to be able to serve it with the best of your intelligence.
Society should be set up in such a way that you can.

I think the desalination problem, fisheries problems have left behind them in their wake a great deal of disillusioned people who have tried to serve society, advise it, and then find not that society
doesn't act the way they thought it should act, but that doesn't even consider the findings in the decisions.
Doesn't even consider them.
That's the denouement, isn't it?
That's the ultimate coup d'etat.
And so now you find them doing their own thing.
Why the hell should they try to serve society?
I mean, science is interesting.
It's a career.
Why not just do it?
Do the things you want to do.
Don't try to serve it.
It doesn't pay attention to you.

See, it's not a question that you say, well, there's 600,000 tons of anchovies that you ought to be able to take out here, maybe a million tons, and enrich California to a considerable extent, learn a great deal more about the utilization of this part of the food web, and so forth, that you should do this.
The fact that society doesn't do that and has
archaic legislation that doesn't allow it to do it, and an engraved public opinion that will not allow it to do it.
That's not the question that they didn't do it, but that they don't even consider the findings, that the people who act on these are acting only on the basis of the advocates'
of the advocates who argue, the public advocates that argue on one side and don't even consider the evidence.

So you find yourself in the position of having devoted quite a bit of your life to really looking into attempting to advise society in these practical utilizations of the ocean and then finding that, not that your findings are not acted on, but rather that your findings are not even considered.
in the evidence, in the decisions.
Quite a disappointment.
